metadata.dc:description: Ménétrier's disease is an infrequent clinical entity characterized by thickening of the gastric folds secondary to hyperplasia of the foveolar mucosa cells, frequently associated with loss of enteric proteins and hypoalbuminemia. Its etiology is unknown, although in the last few years it has been related to Helicobacter pylori infection. We present the case of a 38-year-old man with protein-losing gastroenteropathy caused by Ménétrier's disease, in whom eradication of H. pylori infection was followed by symptom improvement and resolution of hypoalbuminemia. In agreement with the criteria of other authors, we investigate the presence of H. pylori infection in all patients with Ménétrier's disease. When positive, the first-line treatment consists of eradication therapy.
metadata.dc:title: Resolución de la enfermedad de Ménétrier tras la erradicación de la infección por Helicobacter pylori.
[Resolution of Ménétrier's disease after eradication of Helicobacter pylori infection].
